data.message: Daniel Ruller baking soda does not contain sulfites right??

Not the kind I buy. If your worried, try 1/2 a teaspoon a glass of water. Nice thing about it, makes you burp within 5 - 10 minutes, sometimes even quicker and relieves pressure.

Daniel Ruller
this is Bobs red mill baking soda
sodium bicarnoate? is this sulfites. Google does not give difinitive answer on this?
pure sodium bicarbonate is OK for me

Remember Alka Seltzer? Main thing was sodium bicarbonate and something to make it fizz when added to water.
Daniel Ruller yes just wanted to make sure its not sulfited. I get anaphalxis from some sulfites

think i over did it with coconut products trying to get constiaption to move and then i oversulfited plus i was eating a lot of brocolli and sulfur is bad too. Grrrrrrrrr the worst GI distress i ever had. Miserable.
Hope you feel better soon, seems with me it takes time, not much has helped speed up the process. The ginger, baking soda help with the symptoms though.

Daniel Ruller yep i did the ginger tea it was not helping at all. It usually does. Let me tell u tho 5 drops of that slippery elm tincture and it calmed the burning down within a few minutes so i will try more later it helps with a ton of gi stuff.So praying this helps me down the road. Also marshmellow root can help too i have it so will incorporate it too TY for all your help   <3
I take a teaspoon of baking soda in a glass of water. I also use ginger capsules. Helps me with nausea as well.
no
You need baking soda

I know baking powder can contain sulfites
Your right, I never use it

Is bicarbonate of soda the same as baking powder?
Try making some fresh ginger/mint tea. Charcoal tabs will help. Also moving. Walk and do yoga stretches.
does this have sulfite in it? says oixidate sulfite?
Molybdenum glycinate. It wil chelate everything, like active charchoal, but much better.
Slippery elm may help
Apple Cider Vinegar helps me tremendously. Take a shot or mix it in water or apple juice.

How do i calm down my GI from sulfur and sulfite overload?  I am in a lot of pain and have major GI distress? My stomach feels like it is on fire. The bloating and gas and odor is awful. been fighting with this for 2 weeks and its getting worse? I cannot take anything to coat stomach. Will molybendum help? i dont know what to do but everything i eat or drink is causing me discomfort.

Hi Mary - not sure which is the worst offender but I have sample many many tonics (uk) !! The best I have found - that I can personally tolerate is Franklin & Sons. Not carried by any supermarkets except Fortnum & Mason 🙄 but you can get on Amazon. I can do a little fever tree but not much & this brand seems better. Proceed with caution I am not Ana - but very sensitive under 10 ppm.
Also has discovered Eager a fresh juice brand carried byOcado if u don’t want to squeeze your own. I have tried orange & grapefruit
I'd be interested to know as I always feel quite ill after taking fevertree tonic.
So.. there's Quinine Sulphate and Quinine Hydrochloride... My tonics say Quinine Hydrochloride... Anyone know the difference..?! 🤨

I am sulphite intolerant and also cannot have many of the artificial sweeteners.  Luckily I can drink Schweppes Indian Tonic (with sugar & saccharin which is okay for me). So it's G&T to the rescue when friends are having wine with the meal 😀😁

I've just found out that Quinine in tonic water is actually Quinine Sulfate. I never knew..! 🙄
I always thought it was the citric acid in tonic water that I should be weary of. 
Is Quinine a more likely offender to react to than citric acid..? 
Thanks x
Angelina Salwak I have no idea where you got peanuts from. Organic peanut butter is one of my safest foods and I'm very sensitive to processed/added sulfites
Angelina Salwak  I can have organic peanut butter and it’s actually one of my go to foods after a reaction is through and I am starving 😊
Candice Withrow I've seen it a number of places, and react to them myself. What could I be reacting to then? Do they add sulfites to organic bulk peanuts in some places?

http://www.cicbaa.org/pages_us/regimes/sulfites.html 

Here's one source but I've found a few. Could they be referring to something sprayed or added?
Yasmin Ladha man I wish I didn't react! I've had to switch to almond butter. Glad you get to enjoy it, it's a tasty snack! 😊

Angelina Salwak I think most refer to things with sulfites when "conventionally bought", before the widespread availability of health food stores, local made and such. Tiiu has mentioned peanuts can have mold I think, but of course peanuts alone have a famous allergy - have you been tested?  Almond butter is pretty great too!

Angelina Salwak You are right about peanuts though, cause for me I can’t eat the organic ones either but I can have the organic peanut butter, weird right?  
I have even tried the raw peanuts in the shell, boiled it and couldn’t have it.

I can have walnuts and a few cashews now.

Yasmin Ladha you can have peanutbutter but not peanuts? That must be mold or source dependent. Tricky! I really wonder about nuts, like do I just have good access to safe ones? Nuts are on my absolute safest food list, like "lettuce level", and they don't even have to be organic.

Angelina Salwak 
That list is mixing up high sulfur foods with foods which have either natural or added sulfites.
+ histamines.
Not all fermented foods have sulfites either.
Only if a specific yeast is involved.
Lacto-fermentation like in Sauerkraut/yogurt etc. Won’t create natural sulfites.
Candice Withrow Yeah I bought the whole raw peanuts from Whole Foods they were in the shell but maybe I should have taken off the shell and then boiled them?
Yasmin Ladha that seems like a lot of work for peanuts! I don't really eat peanuts by themselves, just peanut butter or in kind bars. They do seem harder to find "raw" than other nuts

The internet sources seem to confuse sulfites and sulfates a TON. I haven't found a comprehensive list. But here's the ones I know of:

Grapes
Pork
Shellfish
Vinegar
Peanuts
Black tea
Alcohol
Fermented products
Grapes are not a natural source of sulfites. No natural sulfites in maple syrup. I think natural sulfites were discussed recently in this group or another. Correct me if I'm wrong, Candice or Tiiu?

Liz My cousins run a maple syrup shack, and they were concerned when they heard about my sulphite allergy. They had heard reports from other maple syrup folks testing above 10ppm on their additive free syrup, and several articles like this one suggest it happens. 

http://www.uvm.edu/~pmrc/sulfite.pdf

Liz the most easily accessible article about naturally occurring sulphites in grapes comes from a wine journal

http://www.organicwinejournal.com/index.php/2008/03/everything-you-wanted-to-know-about-sulfites-but-were-afraid-to-ask/

Liz worth noting that I seem to react with anaphylaxis somewhere around 2PPM too, so I’m rather more vigilant about my sulphites than others may be. my cousins can’t test below 10ppm, but eventually I will probably try their syrup anyways- hopefully I will get lucky and their soil content/processing doesn’t involve enough to cause an issue
Janice Henderson Hopefully Tiiu Ounila can provide light on this. We discussed this recently.

Here is one thread:
https://m.facebook.com/groups/64565870856?view=permalink&id=10155869813910857
The maple syrup discussion must have been in a different sulfite group because I can't find where we discussed it.
No natural sulfites without fermentation, is my understanding. However , organic Maple Syrup does make me tired, while I can eat a ton of honey, so I'm not sure if it's sugar type or what.
Grapes don't have sulfites. They are often sprayed with sulfur dioxide. I can't eat anything processed but organic grapes are generally fine

Candice Health Canadá is pretty clear about soy being a natural source of sulphites without fermentation required.

Also, seeing articles by the syrup and wine industries that explicitly outline naturally occurring sulphites in their foods seem to suggest to me that sulphites exist naturally in some foods and some soils. Though I do fully agree that it seems highly likely fermentation increases sulphites.

To be honest, I’ve been hoping that I can convince Health Canada to dig deeper and release their sources. I want to know how they determined soy was naturally occurring sulphites, and if there’s ways to apply those methods to the things that seem very highly likely to also have naturally occurring sulphites! 

(And I generally have avoided everything anyone ever said might contain sulphites, credible source or not, just because I was so desperate to stop visiting my local ER. Am now slowly adding things back in, but who knows if it’s just my tolerance increasing!)

Janice Henderson it is good to be strict and then slowly add, but that definitely sounds generalized, since some soy is fermented and additive soy certainly is likely to be processed with sulfites. I do not like blanket discouraging something like grapes however, which can be a rare easy, decently healthy treat. It does have a chance of the fungicide so if anaphylactic, fair choice to avoid ! The thing is we've been in this group for 5 +years and have a pretty good grip on what protocols work for most people, taking into consideration for other sensitivities (gluten, legumes, etc) that make it complicated.
I think when they write stuff it's just journalists with a deadline, not anyone who has to live by what they write.

Candice I don’t mean to offend, disrespect, or in anyway undermine your authority as an admin. You’ve had more experience here, absolutely.

On grapes: Liz posted an earlier thread where several anecdotes suggested that quite a few of us do have problems with no-sulphites added grapes. So maybe I’m in the wrong but I’m inclined to think the wine industry guy might be onto something? 

On maple syrup: My cousins came up with a couple articles- the one I posted above was the easily accessible one. The science supports maple syrup containing naturally occurring sulphites, because they aren’t fermenting syrup or adding ingredients and yet have measurable sulphite levels? 

When ancient civilizations added sulphites to things as preservatives, where did those sulphites come from if not naturally derived? Or did they only get it from yeast fermentation? I haven’t found any historical articles to point it out but it’s worth asking.

I think the reason some react to grapes is that organic labelling doesn't prohibit the fungicide, so it's tricky :( I have a similar issues with potatoes because of sulfur being added to soil, at least that's the only thing I can pen it on. 
I will have to read about the syrup! I will say my son, who is also sensitive but has a more liveable tolerance, can have lots of maple syrup. 
No offense taken just clarifying why we may disagree with research. It's not to be dismissive. :)

Janice Henderson SOY is high sulfur food not sulfite containing.
I wish these things will be studied and tested more.
With people who truly have Sulfite issues not on those who think they have.

Liz Costales I am tired of explaining these things over and over again. 
But all these tooics are something we have discussed in the groups many times.
Tiiu Ounila I looked . Wanted to know of a list from a medical dr..

Janet Kubashek I guess you need tp keep looking them.
My lists are based on the info from my doctors and they have been reading the stuff I have written about various things related to the sulfites.
Tiiu Ounila would you be able to tag me of what the info I was looking for please,?

Janet Kubashek not during this weekend because I am only on my phone while working in Lahti Ski Games.
I am ’back in the office’ from Tuesday and hopefully will have time to ho through all the notifications here.
Where are you needing the ’official lists’ ?
Tiiu Ounila I don't want any false info from the internet.
Janet Kubashek 👍🏻

Health Canadá références soy, and makes suggestions that there are others. But no one has passed me credible sources for those.

The wine industry readily admits that grapes are a natural source of sulphites, and the maple syrup industry points out that because of the concentration of their products, maple syrups from areas where naturally occurring sulphites are in the ground can have over 10ppm even! 

https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/food-nutrition/reports-publications/food-safety/sulphites-priority-allergens.html
http://www.learningtarget.com/nosulfites/index.htm

Doctors are not food scientists, unfortunately, and none of them are focused on sulfite allergy treatment. The general understanding is, sulfites are produced naturally only by yeast fermentation, can be added in MANY forms, and can also pop up from eating certain sulfurous foods too rapidly if you have a certain genetic mutation that converts excess sulfur to sulfites when it can't metabolize it adequately.
Grapes are sprayed while on the vine to prevent mold.

Naturally occurring sulfites can be found in products which go through a specific yeast fermentation. Or mixed yeast/bacterial fermentation.
High sulfur foods are not fermented so those won’t have natural sulfites.
The body’s complex metabolism should and would metabolise these high sulfur foods and here the end products are also sulfites- but these are not the same sulfites which you will find in your vinegar, kombucha or no added sulfites wine etc. 
Doctors list have been in most cases inaccurate and also misleading.
Cat it’s definitely because of the soil! Which is why it varies by producer
Janice Henderson it is like winning the lotto when we find one that agrees with us! 😊

It could have to do with the soil...could be grown in basalt/volcanic soil like oats are here in Australia...maple syrup is made from the collection of sap in the tree trunk and roots...it could be absorbed into the tree that way if they are grown on volcanic soil...

Yasmin Ladha I've heard of this peanuts and coke thing! I think it's considered southern in the states. You're when it's a memory it's worth recreating. And relatively simple, compared to other things

Candice Withrow  if only I could drink coke and the peanuts worked for me but hey,  the day will come in future, I am optimistic.  I am very thankful to everyone here that have helped me immensely whether they know it or not, I read everything and try to learn and adapt and so far so good, Tiiu Ounila ‘s  guidance put me a step ahead and i don’t have brain fog anymore and eat a lot of foods now that I couldn’t before.  Hopefully one day, we will have healed our bodies. Amen to that! 💕

It is hard to find safe foods in rural areas. Hope you are doing ok now 👌

Candice Withrow oh so nice. What kind of weather do you have?
Yasmin Ladha it's pretty mild, summers get hot but not as humid as Houston which I'm used to
How did you know you were intolerant to gluten?

Yasmin Ladha when I cut out sulfites I cut out /most/gluten, so when I did have organic, it was isolated and I noticed it caused inflammation, old injuries to hurt and flare up like they were a day old! Plus bloating became obvious because I have a huge baby belly , if I have gluten I look 4 mos pregnant the next morning

Candice Withrow I have a huge baby belly still and I am 66, not proud of it but can’t get rid of it. I do feel bloated sometimes for eg. if I have 2 pitas instead of one etc. yes I get that feeling sometimes that I am all swelled up, maybe I need to avoid gluten for a while?
I will try it for a month to see any difference but otherwise I am so much better than lying in couch every evening with tachycardia and reactions, I really was saved.🙏🏼
Yasmin Ladha are you petite? I'm 5 2 and the baby had nowhere to go but out!

Make sure you have a place to get any b vitamins you may be getting from wheat now, I went through what felt like antidepressant withdrawals once I fully gave it up, was very emotional,but it may have been related to losing a nutrient source
Candice Withrow lol I am petite was 4’10 but past year down to 4 9 . My first born I was in labor many hours it was killing me, the second one couldn’t wait to get out
Candice WithrowI take the Seeking Health Adeno B12 have been good with it, I take it with Kirkland brand Molybdenum chelate and works for me

Yasmin Ladha be sure and get other B's, I think b2 and b1 were in my whole grain breads. My labor was very long and awful as well! Hopefully next time will be ok and at least better by knowing I'm allergic to epidural lol

Candice Withrow  I hear you.  Also this journey not to be taken lightly.  Take Care, Thank you for your advise. I am adding supplements cautiously one at a time but now will recheck the ones I have to make sure. 🙏🏼

Candice Withrow it’s hard work but isn’t it all really hard work for us if we want to eat safe?  I would do it if I could have them even boiled although I love them roasted.

In my primary years I remember the vendors sitting outside our school waiting for children to come out at recess time and for 10 cents Tanzania currency we used to get a whole lot of salted roasted peanuts and the coke cooler was there with the vendor (there were no auto vending machines lol), we used to get the cocoa cola which only came in glass bottles and put some of the peanuts in and drink, it would fizz out, it was cool but more so it tasted heaven and filled you up, you were ready for your next class ha ha.  My father would only allow me one coke a week but I was allowed peanuts and cassava chips, also raw mango slices with salt chilli and lime, soft coconut inside edible shell filled with spiced mashed potatoes and coconut chutney on top sooo delicious.

Wondering if someone can provide a list with sulfites occurring naturally in foods from a dr.? Searched it here and only can find information that's from the internet. Have a list from an allergist with chemical sulfites. Thanks in advance 😁

Practically all Natural Mineral Waters and Sparkling Mineral Waters. 
If you react to natural sulphates then you need to look for those which have lower levels. Natural sulphates are necessary for a healthy gut and brain - and those are needed to heal the gut for instance.

Will do.  My reaction to sulfite ingestion is pretty immediate...heart racing.  If our tap water had sulfites, I'd imagine I'd be experiencing heart racing all day long and I do not.
I drink a ton of tap water every day.  That may be making me sick! OMG

Thanks for reminding us again.  You’re the Best! Hope you are better and having fun 
💕

DASANI water is bottled tap-water which is filtered through sulfite containing filters and lab made sulphates are added to it to make it taste better. 
So anyone in this group, take note to avoid this water. There are other bottled tap waters as well, which might not or might have gone through a filtration with sulfite filters, so unless you have verified with the company skip those and choose either Natural Mineral Waters or Sparkling Mineral waters which are bottled in the source. 
Some distilled waters are safe, again some are not, so you need to do a lot of research by yourself as well. There are so many bottled water companies around the world, that it is impossible to write them all and ask what filters they use. 
For your health it is better to stick to Natural Mineral Waters - why would you pay a high price of bottled tap water with added sulphates ?

All my cleaning products are mostly Melaleuca and H2O@home.  I called some friends who own Forest Grove Coffee Company. Robert called his vendor who in turn called their green bean wholesaler.  None used in their non flavored coffees.  The grower end has not yet responded.  I've got bread going in my bread machine now.  My pharmacist recommended I check the NIH med database as I know more about sulfite ingredients than he does.  I'm going to go pick up my oral ketotifen at Beaverton Pharmacy today.  It seems to really help with my face flushing, then my throat, chest, arms, the hives, the angioedema.  I'm going to endeavor to learn how not to poison myself but first more ketotifen.

I make my own cleaning products. I gave up on finding store bought ones haha. I use vinegar (some may react), hydrogen peroxide and tea tree oil.
Btw, I've found a few safe restaurants here! Harlow, Dick's Kitchen and the margherita pizza at Life of Pi

Tillamook seems to use a lot of artificial ingredients in their products which is super sad because their ice cream looks delicious.

If you ever want to get together and have a shopping adventure, I'd be down!

I've read Rick Williams book, this group files(most), all the indicated websites, plus my own massive Google searches. I live in the Portland, Oregon area USA.  I'm good at research. Reasonably well informed this far. I'm healing from breast cancer treatment and chronic EBV. I used to have severe CFS/ME and POTS. I have EDS and  chronic migraine.  On that note Emgality monthly migraine injectable is life changing.  The snow is about to start AND I'm having abdominal surgery on Tuesday.

3.  What is your experience or opinion regarding sneaky sulfite?  Specifically in household cleaning products and kitchen stuff. I'm aware that bleached coffee filters are awful. What else?  Is dishwasher rinse aid a problem? 
4.  I'm obviously allergic to one or more oral medication and supplements. I know I can't tolerate Teva, Mylan, Pliva and most Breckenridge branded generic medications.  Opinions or experiences?
5.  Desperate to determine safe brand of tomato products. Muir Glen looks okay on no added sulfite. Opinions or recommendations?  Kirkland signature too?
6.  Opinion or experiences with Kirkland signature frozen shrimp. Package states no preservatives. 
7.  Opinion or experience with Safeway/Albertsons Open Nature brand?

Anything you buy *could* have sulphites.

If you’re not super sensitive, you can likely get away with just reading the label on your packaged food. Watch for the naturally occurring sulphites (including eggs & soy) and places sulphites often hide (like corn starch, spices & citric acid).

But otherwise it’s a good idea to call the company. Every company. Ask them about whether they add sulphites, OR if they use them in processing.

For me, I’m sensitive enough that I make them ask their suppliers too, so it takes a while for them to get back to me. But, it’s worthwhile to call: that way you know for sure, and you’ll help educate companies that there are clients who want their products sulphite free 🙂
That mayo
Paprika that isnt organic is likely preserved.
I did eat more of the egg salad(no bread)and my heart did start beating fast and I suddenly felt tired so guess I'd better not eat that again!
if you’re having issues with egg... most mayo has eggs too

Jill Watson Kent what was the brand?

our breads are preservative free....but contain vinegar-which does have sulphites. Yeast also has sulphites in it. The flour also will have an anti-clumping agent in, which has sulphites. I’m guessing the paprika will have anti clumping agents too.

Sherry Sykes Jacobs It was called Outback Bread.  I didn't make note of anything more as I thought I would just go back and get another loaf later....no one knew what I was talking about the first time, second time I went in girl in bakery said they weren't bringing it anymore...we tryed making our own but the yeast is a problem so next going to try Pita Bread.
Jill Watson Kent thanks for sharing!
I only buy bread that says No Sulphites right on the label.  So far I have only found 1 type and now they don't bring it in anymore...

Store-bought bread is pretty horrible. If you can, find bread from a local bakery where you can ask directly what ingredients they use. Also, most flour is bleached and through this process becomes sulfited. Mayonnaise could contain sulfites as well. The only one I've come across that doesn't is Chosen Foods avocado oil mayo. 

Essentially, sulfites have to do with how a food is processed. So one brand of a food item might be safe while another is not. The biggest dangers are emulsifying or bonding ingredients like lecithin/cellulose/maltodextrin/food staches, preservatives like citric acid/tocopherols/guar or xanthan gums/citric acid. Oils are also rough. Corn, vegetable, or canola oils are all sulfited. Any sugar supplement or sweetener will contain sulfites too like corn syrup, glucose, stevia, sucralose, or aspartame.

The easiest way to begin this lifestyle is when you're shopping at the grocery, never go to the center aisles. Everything you can eat will be on the edges like produce, meats, etc. Cook everything from scratch. Pre-packaged foods that are safe are incredibly difficult to find.
Excellent post!
Low fat mayo is evil!  It contains more contaminated ingredients.  Regular Best Foods/Hellman's seems like my best one so far.
An egg salad sandwich...aside from the eggs, which I know have naturally occurring sulfites, what else might contain sulfites...the bread? mayo? paprika?

Yep. I haven't eaten out in almost four years. It is the only way to be sure I'm not poisoned by sulfites. I eat before I go out or go to someone's house or a party. I take my own foods on vacation and book a hotel room with a kitchen.

Sulfite sensitivity (if severe, which mine is) requires a total adjustment of eating habits, unfortunately.

I have an allergist but there doesn't seem to be a test for sulfite allergy.  They just hand a list of things that normally contain sulfites.  And what about the naturally occurring sulfites?  Are those a factor?
We found out because I was in the ER several times a month. Eliminating sulfates is all that helped.
Are sulfites and sulfates the same.

Linnea Fraser Wield they are not.  It took a while to get a good explanation of this, but basically they are different chemicals. SULFITES are the ones banned by FDA for use on salad bars, and the ones in wine.

I will.  This is a much bigger deal than I thought it was.

Linnea Fraser Wieland Yes, it really is, unfortunately. Sometimes I long for my former life, but I do try not to dwell on it. I have anaphylactic type attacks, so I have to be careful about nearly every little thing. Not just foods but skincare products, shampoos, fragrances, makeup, etc.
Oh geez.  Hadn't even thought about the non-food stuff.  I know there is gluten in a lot of those things.

I bring my own wherever I go. 😊💕 but I am so much better that I have adjusted my lifestyle to fit my needs.
I've just stopped ordering anything with a sauce on it because there are sulfites in so many sauce ingredients.  Mayo, vinegar in any form, mustard, concentrated lemon juice are just the most common.

Linnea Fraser Wieland some condiments are ok, but so few. If you're ok with vinegar/mustard then you might be ok with naturally occurring sulfites. Many mayos have binders/emulsifiers and preservatives like soybean oil, canola oil, soy lecithin, maltodextrin and citric acid.
I found a safe mayo at Costco. Their avocado mayo is sulfite free aside from those naturally occurring in vinegar.
I can do some of those...vinegar, mustard for sure.  Possibly mayo.
Even if it’s supposed to be illegal to treat salad bar ingredients, who knows what happens before they get to the restaurant?

We don't eat in restaurants anymore...just gave up...

Candice Withrow I cant tolerate the Methylfolate at all. Maybe need to try follinic!

It's a form well tolerated by those with methyl issues, and folate is generally recommended for those with our issues. I also have iron deficient anemia, and when my ADHD was at it's worst, I was on hormonal IUD and also had premature gray hair. Iron helped, but when I finally was able to tolerate folate and then boosted follinic, my ability to focus really transformed. It is necessary precursor for dopamine/seretonin and melatonin as well. So for me, increasing made me able to sleep without taking melatonin, able to focus, and also means I don't feel suicidal after my period. It's a very very important vitamin, but remember the B's work together and if you only take one it can deplete you of others
https://www.seekinghealth.com/essentials/vitamins/b-vitamins/folate/folinic-acid
They also sell it with hydroxy B12, which is only form that works for me, but I take separately because I'm a control freak

Linnea Fraser Wieland my seizures are the type with the unfortunate name of "psychosomatic" (even though they aren't -- it's what they call seizures that you stay conscious during). also, activated charcoal can really mitigate bad reactions. Just don't take it within 2 hours if your supplements or medications as it affects absorption.

Linnea Fraser Wieland they're a documented allergen but I don't think it's fully understood where they hide. For example Corn harvested to be used in corn products (like corn flour, syrup or meal) is harvested and then soaked in vats of sulphites before processing. So if a friend made some homemade candy and said there were no sulphites in it, but was made with corn syrup I wouldn't eat it.

They're one of the listed allergens in food in Europe but nobody wants to test for them or really knows what they are/what contains them. Definitely don't believe they're in anything non food related, or where they aren't listed as an ingredient.
Leslie Basil Payne, gotcha. Didn’t know that.

Linnea Fraser Wieland as far as I know, food allergies can't be treated this way. Like lactose, gluten, sulfur, etc. It's your body's inability to process, so not an allergy like pollen.
Angelina Salwak, are we missing an enzyme that processes sulfites?
Angelina Salwak, so like lactose, is there a pill we can take like Lactase that will help?

Linnea Fraser Wieland yes, kind of. Lactase I feel is often misused and mis-adervertised. Many brands claim it will allow you to eat lactose again but really it just helps your body process it, but won't prevent it from doing damage to your system.

Many of us take molybdenum to help process sulfites that we naturally come into contact with. It can help lessen the severity of a reaction as well. But it won't allow you to be able to eat the standard American diet without doing some serious damage to your digestive system unfortunately.
This is a sulfite free brand of molybdenum.

For any supplements, do research into bioavailability. Many supplements on the market contain vitamins in forms that aren't actually able to be processed or absorbed by the body or contain additives like gelatin, starch or natural flavors. Chelated forms are often more easily absorbed. NOW and Solgar brands are often made bioavailable and sulfite free!

Yeah it was organic - from Davids tea in Canada... which is why I had hoped it was safe. So frustrating :(

Kristen David’s Teas has a lot of ingredients which get citric acid & sulphites added to them. In the past I’ve had trouble with cross contamination of nuts (different allergy) in some of their teas, so I would suspect that there’s likely cross contamination with sulphites, or that one or more of the herbs/spices was processed with sulphites.

In Canada, if the end result has more than 10 PPM they have to label sulphites present, but if it’s under that threshold they don’t have to label it; particularly if sulphites were used in the processing of the item. 

Generally speaking if you’re reacting under 10ppm... you may want to consider calling the company and checking a) if they use sulphites at any point in their process and b) if there are sulphites used by their suppliers in the ingredients. It usually takes a couple days for companies to get back to you, but the effort is worthwhile because then the next time someone calls, they’ll have the information... or at least be more aware that sulphite allergies & sensitivities exist!
